Sents: Senator Sanders, to you first.

Sents: Coming off the results in Iowa and New Hampshire, there are many voters who are taking a closer look at you, and your ideas, and they're asking how big a role do you foresee for the federal government?

Sents: It's already spending 21% of the entire U.S. economy.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: How much larger would government be in the lives of Americans under a Sanders presidency?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, to put that in a context, Judy, I think we have to understand that in the last 30 years in this country there has been a massive transfer of wealth going from the hands of working families into the top one-tenth of 1% whose percentage of wealth has doubled.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In other words, the very rich are getting richer, almost everybody is going — getting poorer.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What I believe is the United States, in fact, should join the rest of the industrialized world and guarantee healthcare to all people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Our Medicare for all single-payer proposal will save the average middle class family $5,000 a year.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I do believe that in the year 2016 we have to look in terms of public education as colleges as part of public education making public colleges and universities tuition free.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I believe that when real unemployment is close to 10%, and when our infrastructure, our roads, our bridges, our water systems, Flint, Michigan comes to mind.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Our waste water plants, our rail, our airports, in many places are disintegrating.

Sents: Yeah, we can create 13 million jobs by rebuilding our infrastructure at a cost of a trillion dollars.

Sents: But, my question is how big would government be?

Sents: Would there be any limit on the size of the role of government...

Sents: ... Of course there will be a limit, but when today you have massive levels of income and wealth inequality, when the middle class is disappearing, you have the highest rate of child poverty of almost any major country on Earth.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Yes, in my view, the government of a democratic society has a moral responsibility to play a vital role in making sure all of our people have a decent standard of living.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Judy, I think that the best analysis that I've seen based on Senator Sanders plans is that it would probably increase the size of the federal government by about 40%, but what is most concerning to me is that in looking at the plans — let's take healthcare for example.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Last week in a CNN town hall, the Senator told a questioner that the questioner would spend about $500 dollars in taxes to get about $5,000 dollars in healthcare.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Every progressive economist who has analyzed that says that the numbers don't add up, and that's a promise that cannot be kept, and it's really important now that we are getting into the rest of the country that both of us are held to account for explaining what we are proposing because, especially with healthcare, this is not about math.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is about people's lives, and we should level with the American people about what we can do to make sure they get quality affordable healthcare.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, let us level with the American people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Secretary Clinton has been going around the country saying Bernie Sanders wants to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, people are going to lose their MedicAid, they're going to lose their CHIP program.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have fought my entire life to make sure that healthcare is a right for all people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We're not going to dismantle everything.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But, here is the truth.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Twenty-nine million people have no health insurance today in America.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We pay, by far, the highest prices in the world for prescription drugs.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: One out of five Americans can't even afford the prescriptions their doctors are writing.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Millions of people have high deductibles and co-payments.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What I said, and let me repeat it, I don't know what economists Secretary Clinton is talking to, but what I have said, and let me repeat it, that yes, the middle — the family right in the middle of the economy would pay $500 dollars more in taxes, and get a reduction in their healthcare costs of $5,000 dollars.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In my view healthcare is a right of all people, not a privilege, and I will fight for that.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I can only say that we both share the goal of universal health care coverage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, before it was called Obamacare, it was called Hillarycare.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And I took on the drug companies and I took on the insurance companies to try to get us universal health care coverage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause] And why I am a staunch supporter of President Obama's principal accomplishment — namely the Affordable Care Act — is because I know how hard it was to get that done.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We are at 90 percent coverage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have to get the remaining 10.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I've set forth very specific plans about how to get costs down, especially prescription drug costs.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And it is difficult to in any way argue with the goal that we both share.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I think the American people deserve to know specifically how this would work.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: If it's Medicare for all, then you no longer have the Affordable Care Act, because the Affordable Care Act, as you know very well, is based on the insurance system, based on exchanges, based on a subsidy system.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The Children's Health Insurance Program, which I helped to create, which covers 8 million kids, is also a different kind of program.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So if you're having Medicare for all, single-payer, you need to level with people about what they will have at the end of the process you are proposing.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And based on every analysis that I can find by people who are sympathetic to the goal, the numbers don't add up, and many people will actually be worse off than they are right now.

Sents: Final thought, Senator.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That is absolutely inaccurate.

Sents: Look, here is the reality, folks.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: There is one major country on Earth that does not guarantee health care to all people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: There is one major country — the United States — which ends up spending almost three times per capita what they do in the U.K. guaranteeing health care to all people, 50 percent more than they do in France guaranteeing health care to all people, far more than our Canadian neighbors, who guarantee health care to all people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Please do not tell me that in this country, if — and here's the if — we have the courage to take on the drug companies, and have the courage to take on the insurance companies, and the medical equipment suppliers, if we do that, yes, we can guarantee health care to all people in a much more cost effective way.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, let me just — let me just say, once again...[applause]...that, having been in the trenches fighting for this, I believe strongly we have to guarantee health care.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I believe we are on the path to doing that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The last thing we need is to throw our country into a contentious debate about health care again.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And we are not England.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We are not France.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We inherited a system that was set up during World War II; 170 million Americans get health insurance right now through their employers.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So what we have tried to do and what President Obama succeeded in doing was to build on the health care system we have, get us to 90 percent coverage.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have to get the other 10 percent of the way to 100.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I far prefer that and the chances we have to be successful there than trying to start all over again, gridlocking our system, and trying to get from zero to 100 percent.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: In my case, whether it's health care, or getting us to debt-free tuition, or moving us toward paid family leave, I have been very specific about where I would raise the money, how much it would cost, and how I would move this agenda forward.

Sents: I've tried to be as specific to answer questions so that my proposals can be vetted, because I feel like we have to level with people for the very reason, Gwen, that you are mentioning.

Sents: There is a great deal of skepticism about the federal government.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I'm aware of that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: It comes from the right, from the left, from people on all sides of the political spectrum.

Sents: So we have a special obligation to make clear what we stand for, which is why I think we should not make promises we can't keep, because that will further, I think, alienate Americans from understanding and believing we can together make some real changes in people's lives.

Sents: But I haven't heard either of you put a price tag on your — you say...[crosstalk]

Sents: I will put a price tag.

Sents: My price tag is about $100 billion a year.

Sents: And again, paid for.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And what I have said is I will not throw us further into debt.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I believe I can get the money that I need by taxing the wealthy, by closing loopholes, the things that we are way overdue for doing.

Sents: And I think once I'm in the White House we will have enough political capital to be able to do that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I am conscious of the fact that we have to also be very clear, especially with young people, about what kind of government is going to do what for them and what it will cost.

Sents: Senator?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, Secretary Clinton, you're not in the White House yet.

Sents: And let us be clear that every proposal that I have introduced has been paid for.

Sents: For example, all right, who in America denies that we have an infrastructure that is crumbling?

Sents: Who denies that real unemployment today, including those who have given up looking for work and are working part-time is close to 10 percent?

Sents: Who denies that African-American youth unemployment, real, is over 50 percent.

Sents: We need to create jobs.

Sents: So yes, I will do away with the outrageous loopholes that allow profitable multinational corporations to stash billions of dollars in the Cayman Islands and Bermuda and in a given year pay zero, zero in federal income tax.

Sents: Yes, I'm going to do away with that.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We will use those proceeds, a hundred billion a year, to invest in rebuilding our infrastructure.

Sents: Yes, I believe that as a result of the illegal behavior on Wall Street, that they are a Wall Street that drove this country into the worst economic downturn since the Great Recession — Great Depression.

Sents: Yes, I do believe that now after the American people bailed Wall Street out, yes, they should pay a Wall Street speculation tax so that we can make public colleges and universities tuition-free.

Sents: We bailed them out.

Sents: Now it is their time to help the middle class.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: One of them being that if you don't have some agreement within the system from states and from families and from students, it's hard to get to where we need to go.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: Very brief, thank you.

Sents: And that free education of extraordinary accomplishment was from first grade to 12th grade.

Sents: This is 2016.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: So I'm going to keep making that case.

Sents: I'm going to keep making sure that everything I've done, everything that I stand for is going to be well known.

Sents: That's what I'm working towards.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: But it doesn't change my view that we need to empower everyone, women and men, to make the best decisions in their minds that they can make.

Sents: And when it comes to the issues that are really on the front lines as to whether we're going to have equal pay, paid family leave, some opportunity for, you know, women to go as far as their hard work and talent take them, I think that we still have some barriers to knock down, which is why that's at the core of my campaign.

Sents: I would note, just for a historic aside, somebody told me earlier today we've had like 200 presidential primary debates, and this is the first time there have been a majority of women on the stage.

Sents: So, you know, we'll take our progress wherever we can find it.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: [laughter]

Sents: I am very proud, if my memory is not correct — I think I am — that I have a lifetime — and I've been in Congress a few years — a lifetime 100 percent pro-choice voting record.

Sents: I am very proud that over the years we have had the support in my state of Vermont from very significant majorities of women.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: So I'm asking women, I'm asking men, to support me because I'm ready to go into the White House on January 20th, 2017 and get to work on both domestic and foreign policy challenges.

Sents: [applause]

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: What can we do across the nation to address this?"

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: Senator Sanders.

Sents: So what we have to do is the radical reform of a broken criminal justice system.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents:
[applause]

Sents: [applause]

Sents: And we know of the tragic, terrible event that lead to the death of Dontre Hamilton right here in Milwaukee, a young man unarmed, who should still be with us.

Sents: And so do I.

Sents: There have been some good recommendations about what needs to happen.

Sents: President Obama's policing commission came out with some.

Sents: I have fully endorsed those.

Sents: But we have to restore policing that will actually protect the communities that police officers are sworn to protect.

Sents: So, when we talk about criminal justice reform, and ending the era of mass incarceration, we also have to talk about jobs, education, housing, and other ways of helping communities.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: [applause]

Sents: Well, I'm just not sure I agree completely with that assessment.

Sents: I think under President Obama we have seen a lot of advances, the Affordable Care Act has helped more African Americans than any other group to get insurance, to be taken care of, but we also know a lot more than we did.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have a lot more social media, we have everybody with a cellphone.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So, we are seeing the dark side of the remaining systemic racism that we have to root out in our society.

Sents: I think President Obama has set a great example.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think he has addressed a lot of these issues that have been quite difficult, but he has gone forward.

Sents: Now, what we have to do is to build on an honest conversation about where we go next.

Sents: We now have much more information about what must be done to fix our criminal justice system.

Sents: We now have some good models about how better to provide employment, housing and education.

Sents: I think what President Obama did was to exemplify the importance of this issue as our first African American president, and to address it both from the President's office, and through his advocacy, such as working with young men, and Mrs. Obama's work with young women.

Sents: But, we can't rest.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have work to do, and we now know a lot more than we ever did before.

Sents: So, it's going to be my responsibility to make sure we move forward to solve these problems that are now out in the open.

Sents: Nobody can deny them.

Sents: To use the Justice Department, as we just saw, they have said they are going to sue Ferguson, that entered into a consent agreement, and then tried to back out.

Sents: So, we're going to enforce the law, we're going to change policing practices, we're going to change incarceration practices, but we're also going to emphasize education, jobs, and housing.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Senator Sanders?

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: [applause]

Sents: Well, I think, Judy, what has to be appreciated is that, as a result of the disastrous and illegal behavior on Wall Street, millions of lives were hurt.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: People lost their jobs, their homes, their life savings.

Sents: Turns out that the African-American community and the Latino community were hit especially hard.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: As I understand it, the African-American community lost half of their wealth as a result of the Wall Street collapse.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So when you have childhood African-American poverty rates of 35 percent, when you have youth unemployment at 51 percent, when you have unbelievable rates of incarceration — which, by the way, leaves the children back home without a dad or even a mother — clearly, we are looking at institutional racism.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We are looking at an economy in which the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And sadly, in America today, in our economy, a whole lot of those poor people are African-American.

Sents: So race relation was be better under a Sanders presidency than they've been?

Sents: Absolutely, because what we will do is say, instead of giving tax breaks to billionaires, we are going to create millions of jobs for low-income kids so they're not hanging out on street corners.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We're going to make sure that those kids stay in school or are able to get a college education.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I think when you give low-income kids — African-American, white, Latino kids — the opportunities to get their lives together, they are not going to end up in jail.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: They're going to end up in the productive economy, which is where we want them.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: Let me turn this on its head, because when we talk about race in this country, we always talk about African-Americans, people of color.

Sents: I want to talk about white people, OK?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: White people?

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: I know.

Sents: [laughter] So many people will be surprised to find out that we are sitting in one of the most racially polarized metropolitan areas in the country.

Sents: By the middle of this century, the nation is going to be majority nonwhite.

Sents: Our public schools are already there.

Sents: If working-class, white Americans are about to be outnumbered, are already underemployed in many cases, and one study found they are dying sooner, don't they have a reason to be resentful, Senator — Secretary Clinton?

Sents: Look, I am deeply concerned about what's happening in every community in America, and that includes white communities, where we are seeing an increase in alcoholism, addiction, earlier deaths.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: People with a high school education or less are not even living as long as their parents lived.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is a remarkable and horrifying fact.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And that's why I've come forward with, for example, a plan to revitalize coal country, the coalfield communities that have been so hard hit by the changing economy, by the reduction in the use of coal.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, coal miners and their families who helped turn on the lights and power our factories for generations are now wondering, has our country forgotten us?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Do people not care about all of our sacrifice?

Sents: And I'm going to do everything I can to address distressed communities, whether they are communities of color, whether they are white communities, whether they are in any part of our country.

Sents: I particularly appreciate the proposal that Congressman Jim Clyburn has — the 10-20-30 proposal — to try to spend more federal dollars in communities with persistent generational poverty.

Sents: And you know what?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: If you look at the numbers, there are actually as many, if not more white communities that are truly being left behind and left out.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So, yes, I do think it would be a terrible oversight not to try to address the very real problems that white Americans — particularly those without a lot of education whose jobs have — you know, no longer provided them or even no longer present in their communities, because we have to focus where the real hurt is.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And that's why, as president, I will look at communities that need special help and try to deliver that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Sents: Senator — Senator, I want you to respond to that, but I also want you to — am I wrong?

Sents: Is it even right to be describing this as a matter of race?

Sents: Yeah, you can, because African-Americans and Latinos not only face the general economic crises of low wages, and high unemployment, and poor educational opportunities, but they face other problems, as well.

Sents: So, yes, we can talk about it as a racial issue.

Sents: But it is a general economic issue.

Sents: And here's what the economic issue is.

Sents: The wages that high school graduates receive today are significantly less, whether you are white or black, than they used to be.

Sents: Because of a series of disastrous trade policies which have allowed corporate America through NAFTA and Permanent Normal Trade Relations with China, Secretary Clinton and I disagree on those issues.

Sents: But view is those trade policies have enabled corporate America to shut down in this country, throw millions of people out on the street.

Sents: Now no one thinks that working in the factory is the greatest job in the world.

Sents: But you know what, you can make a middle class wage, you have decent health care, decent benefits.

Sents: You once had a pension.

Sents: Those jobs, in many cases, are now gone.

Sents: They're off to China.

Sents: Now you are a worker, white worker, black worker, who had a decent job, that manufacturing job is gone.

Sents: What have you got now?

Sents: You are working at McDonald's?

Sents: That is why there is massive despair all over this country.

Sents: People have worked their entire lives.

Sents: They're making a half, two-thirds what they used to make.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Their kids are having a hard time finding any work at all.

Sents: And that's why this study, which shows that if you can believe it today, for white working class people between 45 and 54, life expectancy is actually going down.

Sents: Suicide, alcoholism, drugs, that's why we need to start paying attention to the needs of working families in this country, and not just a handful of billionaires who have enormous economic and political power.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: Should an undocumented family watching this debate tonight, say, in Nevada, rest easy, not fear of further deportations under a Sanders presidency?

Sents: I believe that we have got to pass comprehensive immigration reform, something that I strongly supported.

Sents: I believe that we have got to move toward a path toward citizenship.

Sents: I agree with President Obama who used executive orders to protect families because the Congress, the House was unable or refused to act.

Sents: And in fact I would go further.

Sents: What would motivate me and what would be the guiding light for me in terms of immigration reform, Judy, is to bring families together, not divide them up.

Sents: And let me say this also.

Sents: Somebody who is very fond of the president, agrees with him most of the time, I disagree with his recent deportation policies.

Sents: And I would not support those.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Bottom line is a path towards citizenship for 11 million undocumented people, if Congress doesn't do the right thing, we use the executive orders of the president.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: I strongly support the president's executive actions.

Sents: I hope the Supreme Court upholds them.

Sents: I think there is constitutional and legal authority for the president to have done what he did.

Sents: I am against the raids.

Sents: I'm against the kind of inhumane treatment that is now being visited upon families, waking them up in the middle of the night, rounding them up.

Sents: I'm a strong supporter of comprehensive immigration reform.

Sents: Have been ever since I was in the Senate.

Sents: I was one of the original sponsors of the DREAM Act.

Sents: I voted for comprehensive immigration reform in 2007.

Sents: Senator Sanders voted against it at that time.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Because I think we have to get to comprehensive immigration reform with a path to citizenship.

Sents: And as president I would expand enormous energy, literally call every member of Congress that I thought I could persuade.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Hopefully after the 2016 election, some of the Republicans will come to their senses and realize we are not going to deport 11 or 12 million people in this country.

Sents: And they will work with me to get comprehensive immigration reform.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: That was not, as I understand it, the secretary's position.

Sents: In terms of 2007 immigration reform, yeah, I did vote against it.

Sents: I voted against it because the Southern Poverty Law Center, among other groups, said that the guest-worker programs that were embedded in this agreement were akin to slavery.

Sents: Akin to slavery, where people came into this country to do guest work were abused, were exploited, and if they stood up for their rights, they'd be thrown out of this country.

Sents: So it wasn't just me who opposed it.

Sents: It was LULAC, one of the large Latino organizations in this country.

Sents: It was the AFL-CIO.

Sents: It was some of the most progressive members of the United States Congress who opposed it for that reason.

Sents: But we are where we are right now.

Sents: And where we are right now is we have got to stand up to the Trumps of the world who are trying to divide us up.

Sents: What we have to do right now is bring our people together and understand that we must provide a path towards citizenship for 11 million undocumented people.

Sents: Two quick responses.

Sents: One, with respect to the Central American children, I made it very clear that those children needed to be processed appropriately, but we also had to send a message to families and communities in Central America not to send their children on this dangerous journey in the hands of smugglers.

Sents: I've also called for the end of family detention, for the end of privately-run detention centers, along with private prisons, which I think are really against the common good and the rule of law.

Sents: And with respect to the 2007 bill, this was Ted Kennedy's bill.

Sents: And I think Ted Kennedy had a very clear idea about what needed to be done.

Sents: And I was proud to stand with him and support it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Sents: I'd like...

Sents: Well, let me just respond.

Sents: I worked with Ted Kennedy.

Sents: He was the chairman of my committee.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I loved Ted Kennedy.

Sents: But on this issue, when you have one of the large Latino organizations in America saying vote no, and you have the AFL-CIO saying vote no, and you have leading progressive Democrats, in fact, voting no, I don't apologize for that vote.

Sents: But in terms of the children, I don't know to whom you're sending a message.

Sents: Who are you sending a message to?

Sents: These are children who are leaving countries and neighborhoods where their lives are at stake.

Sents: That was the fact.

Sents: I don't think we use them to send a message.

Sents: I think we welcome them into this country and do the best we can to help them get their lives together.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: Well, that just wasn't — that just wasn't the fact, Senator.

Sents: The fact is that there was a great effort made by the Obama administration and others to really send a clear message, because we knew that so many of these children were being abused, being treated terribly while they tried to get to our border.

Sents: So we have a disagreement on this.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think now what I've called for is counsel for every child so that no child has to face any kind of process without someone who speaks and advocates for that child so that the right decision hopefully can be made.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Sents: If you would allow me now to move on, we've been talking about children.

Sents: How will you as president work to ensure low-income seniors get their basic needs met?"

Sents: Start with you, Senator Sanders.

Sents: OK. You know, you judge a nation not by the number of millionaires and billionaires it has, but by how you treat, we treat, the most vulnerable and fragile people in our nation.

Sents: And by those standards, we're not doing particularly well.

Sents: We have the highest rate of childhood poverty among almost any major country on Earth.

Sents: And in terms of seniors, there are millions of seniors — and I've talked to them in my state of Vermont and all over this country — who are trying to get by on $11,000, $12,000, $13,000 a year Social Security.

Sents: And you know what?

Sents: You do the arithmetic.

Sents: You can't get by on $11,000, $12,000, $13,000 a year.

Sents: And here's an area where Secretary Clinton and I believe we have a difference.

Sents: I have long supported the proposition that we should lift the cap on taxable income coming into the Social Security Trust Fund, starting at $250,000.

Sents: [applause] And when we — and when we do that, we don't do what the Republicans want, which is to cut Social Security.

Sents: We do what the American people want, to expand Social Security by $1,300 a year for people under $16,000, and we extend the life of Social Security for 58 years.

Sents: Yes, the wealthiest people, the top 1.5 percent, will pay more in taxes.

Sents: But a great nation like ours should not be in a position where elderly people are cutting their pills in half, where they don't have decent nutrition, where they can't heat their homes in the wintertime.

Sents: That is not what America should be about.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: If elected president, I will do everything I can to expand Social Security benefits, not just for seniors, but for disabled veterans, as well.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Sents: I think — I think it's fair to say we don't have a disagreement.

Sents: We both believe there has to be more money going into the Social Security system.

Sents: I've said I'm looking at a couple of different ways, one which you mentioned, Senator, but also trying to expand the existing tax to passive income that wealthy people have so that we do get more revenue into the Social Security Trust Fund.

Sents: I have a slightly different approach, though, about what we should do with that initially.

Sents: First, rather than expand benefits for everyone, I do want to take care of low-income seniors who worked at low-wage jobs.

Sents: I want to take care of women.

Sents: When the Social Security program was started in the 1930s, not very many women worked.

Sents: And women have been disadvantaged ever since.

Sents: They do not get any credit for their care-taking responsibilities.

Sents: And the people who are often the most hard-hit are widows, because when their spouse dies, they can lose up to one-half of their Social Security monthly payment.

Sents: So we have no disagreement about the need to buttress Social Security, get more revenue into the program.

Sents: But I want to start by helping those people who are most at risk, the ones who, yes, are cutting their pills in half, who don't believe they can make the rent, who are worried about what comes next for them.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In all due respect...[applause]...In all due respect, Secretary Clinton, a lot of the progressive groups, the online groups have really asked you a simple question.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Are you coming onboard a proposal?

Speaker: SANDERS

Sents: [applause]

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Senator, let me — let me move on to another country with which the U.S. has a complicated relationship, Senator Sanders, and that's Russia.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: On the one hand, we're aware that Russia is a country that the United States needs to cooperate with.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Just tonight, Secretary of State John Kerry has announced what appears to be an agreement with the Russians to lead — that could lead toward a ceasefire in Syria, would be the first cessation of conflict in that country, in that civil war in five years, but it comes at a very high price, because not only have all — have we seen the deaths, the removal of so many people, millions of people, we now see the Russians in the last few weeks have bombed in a way that benefits President Assad, has not gone after ISIS.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: So my question to you is, when it comes to dealing with Russia, are you prepared — how hard are you prepared to be?

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Are you prepared to institute further economic sanctions?

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Would you be prepared to move militarily if Russia moves on Eastern Europe?

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: It seems to me that Russia recently has gotten the better of the United States.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, this is what I would say.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It is a complicated relationship.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I congratulate Secretary of State John Kerry and the president for working on this agreement.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: As you've indicated, what is happening in Syria, the number of people, the hundreds of thousands of people who have been killed — men, women, 20,000 children, the people who are forced to flee their own country — their own country — it is unspeakable.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It is a real horror.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Now, what I think is that right now we have got to do our best in developing positive relations with Russia.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But let's be clear: Russia's aggressive actions in the Crimea and in Ukraine have brought about a situation where President Obama and NATO — correctly, I believe — are saying, you know what, we're going to have to beef up our troop level in that part of the world to tell Putin that his aggressiveness is not going to go unmatched, that he is not going to get away with aggressive action.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I happen to believe that Putin is doing what he is doing because his economy is increasingly in shambles and he's trying to rally his people in support of him.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But bottom line is: The president is right.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We have to put more money.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We have to work with NATO to protect Eastern Europe against any kind of Russian aggression.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, with respect to Syria, I really do appreciate the efforts that Secretary Kerry has made.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The agreement on humanitarian relief now needs to be implemented, because there are enclaves that are literally filled with starving people throughout Syria.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The agreement on a cease-fire, though, is something that has to be implemented more quickly than the schedule that the Russians agreed to.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, the Russians wanted to buy time.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Are they buying time to continue their bombardment on behalf of the Assad regime to further decimate what's left of the opposition, which would be a grave disservice to any kind of eventual cease-fire?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So I know Secretary Kerry is working extremely hard to try to move that cease-fire up as quickly as possible.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I would add this.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, the Security Council finally got around to adopting a resolution.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: At the core of that resolution is an agreement I negotiated in June of 2012 in Geneva, which set forth a cease-fire and moving toward a political resolution, trying to bring the parties at stake in Syria together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is incredibly complicated, because we've got Iran as a big player, in addition to Russia.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have Saudi Arabia, Turkey, and others who have very important interests in their view.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is one of the areas I've disagreed with Senator Sanders on, who has called for Iranian troops trying to end civil war in Syria, which I think would be a grave mistake.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Putting Iranian troops right on the border of the Golan right next to Israel would be a nonstarter for me.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Trying to get Iran and Saudi Arabia to work together, as he has suggested in the past, is equally a nonstarter.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So let's support what Secretary Kerry and the president are doing, but let's hope that we can accelerate the cease-fire, because I fear that the Russians will continue their bombing, try to do everything they can to destroy what's left of the opposition.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And remember, the Russians have not gone after ISIS or any of the other terrorist groups.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So as we get a cease-fire and maybe some humanitarian corridors, that still leaves the terrorist groups on the doorstep of others in Syria, Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, and the like.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So we've got some real work to do, and let's try to make sure we actually implement what has been agreed to with the Russians.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Let me just — just say this.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: For a start, the secretary and I disagree — and I think the president does not agree with her — in terms of the concept of a no-fly zone in Syria.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I think you do have a humanitarian tragedy there, as I mentioned a moment ago.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I applaud Secretary Kerry and the president for trying to put together this agreement.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Let's hope that it holds.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But furthermore, what we have got to do, I'm sorry, yes, I do believe that we have got to do everything that we can, and it will not happen tomorrow.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But I do hope that in years to come, just as occurred with Cuba, 10, 20 years ago, people would say, reach normalized relations with Cuba.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And by the way, I hope we can end the trade embargo with Cuba as well.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But the idea that we some day maybe have decent relations with Iran, maybe put pressure on them so they end their support for terrorism around the world, yes, that is something I want to achieve.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I believe that the best way to do that is to be aggressive, to be principled, but to have the goal of trying to improve relations.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That's how you make peace in the world.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: You sit down and you work with people, you make demands of people, in this case demanding Iran stop the support of international terrorism.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, I respectfully disagree.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think we have achieved a great deal with the Iranian nuclear agreement to put a lid on the Iranian nuclear weapons program.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: That has to be enforced absolutely with consequences for Iran at the slightest deviation from their requirements under the agreement.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I do not think we should promise or even look toward normalizing relations because we have a lot of other business to get done with Iran.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Yes, they have to stop being the main state sponsor of terrorism.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Yes, they have to stop trying to destabilize the Middle East, causing even more chaos.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Yes, they've got to get out of Syria.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: They've got to quit sponsoring Hezbollah and Hamas.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: They have got to quit trying to ship rockets into Gaza that can be used against Israel.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have a lot of work to do with Iran before we ever say that they could move toward normalized relations with us.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We have a lot of work to do.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We have a lot of work to do.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But I recall when Secretary Clinton ran against then-Senator Obama, she was critical of him for suggesting that maybe you want to talk to Iran, that you want to talk to our enemies.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have no illusion.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Of course you are right.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Iran is sponsoring terrorism in many parts of the world, destabilizing areas.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Everybody knows that.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But our goal is, in fact, to try over a period of time to, in fact, deal with our enemies, not just ignore that reality.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [crosstalk]

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Senator Sanders, from a debate in 2008, quote what I said.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The question was, would you meet with an adversary without conditions?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I said no.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And in fact, in Obama administration, we did not meet with anybody without conditions.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: That is the appropriate approach in order to get the results that you are seeking.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: No, I think the idea was that president — then-Senator Obama was wrong for suggesting that it is a good idea to talk to your opponents.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It's easier to talk to your friends.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It's harder to talk to your enemies.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I think we should do both.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: Let me move on.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: You have both mentioned the humanitarian tragedies which have been an outgrowth in part of what has happened in Syria and in Libya.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: More than a million refugees entered Europe in 2015.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: Another 76,000 just last month, that is about 2,000 arrivals every day.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: Nearly 400 people have been lost at sea so far this year, crossing the Mediterranean.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: And there are reports that 10,000 children are missing.

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: If we are leaders in this world, where should the U.S. be on this?

Speaker: IFILL
Sents: What should the United States be doing, Secretary Clinton?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, I was pleased that NATO announced just this week that they're going to start doing patrols in the Mediterranean, in the Aegean, to try to interdict the smugglers, to try to prevent the kind of tragedies that we have seen all too often, also to try to prevent more refugees from coming to the European Union.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And it's especially significant that they are working with both Turkey and Greece in order to do this.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: With respect to the United States, I think our role in NATO, our support for the E.U., as well as our willingness to take refugees so long as they are thoroughly vetted and that we have confidence from intelligence and other sources that they can come to our country, we should be doing our part.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And we should back up the recent donors conference to make sure we have made our contribution to try to deal with the enormous cost that these refugees are posing to Turkey and to members of the E.U.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: in particular.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is a humanitarian catastrophe.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: There is no other description of it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So we do as the United States have to support our friends, our allies in Europe.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have to stand with them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have to provide financial support to them.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We have to provide the NATO support to back up the mission that is going on.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And we have to take properly vetted refugees ourselves.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: A couple of years ago, I had the opportunity to go on a congressional delegation.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I went to one of these Turkish refugee camps right on the border of Syria.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And what a sad sight that was: Men, women, children forced out of their homes.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And Turkey, by the way, did a very decent thing, providing what was reasonable housing and conditions for those people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It seems to me that given our history as a nation that has been a beacon of hope for the oppressed, for the downtrodden, that I very strongly disagree with those Republican candidates who say, you know what, we've got to turn our backs on women and children who left their home with nothing, nothing at all.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That is not what America is supposed to be about.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So I believe that working with Europe — and, by the way, you know, we've got some very wealthy countries there in that part of the world.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: You got Kuwait and you got Qatar and you got Saudi Arabia.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: They have a responsibility, as well.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But I think this is a worldwide — that the entire world needs to come together to deal with this horrific refugee crisis we're seeing from Syria and Afghanistan, as well.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Sents: And we have a final question from our Facebook family.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: And it goes to Senator Sanders.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: It comes from Robert Andrews.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: He's a 40-year-old stay-at-home dad in Dover, Massachusetts.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: He says, "The world has seen many great leaders in the course of human history.

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: Can you name two leaders — one American and one foreign — who would influence your foreign policy decisions?

Speaker: WOODRUFF
Sents: And why do you see them as — why are they influential?"

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: You know, Franklin Delano Roosevelt took the oath of office in 1933 at a time when 25 percent of the American people were unemployed, country was in incredible despair.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And he stood before the American people and he said, "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself," a profound statement that gave the American people the courage to believe that, yes, we could get out of that terrible depression.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And then what he did is redefine the role of government.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: You know, you had Herbert Hoover before that saying, no, we got to only worry about the deficit.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So what if mass unemployment exists?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So what if children are going hungry?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That's not the role of the government.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And when FDR said, "Yeah, it is," that we're going to use all of the resources that we have to create jobs, to build homes, to feed people, to protect the farmers, we are a nation which if we come together there is nothing that we could not accomplish.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And kind of — that's what I see our campaign is about right now.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In this particular moment of serious crises, saying to the American people don't give up on the political process.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: don't listen to the Trumps of the world and allowing them to divide us.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: If we reengage and get involved, yeah, we can have health care for all people, we can make public colleges and universities tuition-free.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We do not have to have massive levels of income and wealth inequality.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In the same light, as the foreign leader, Winston Churchill's politics were not my politics.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: He was kind of a conservative guy in many respects.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But nobody can deny that as a wartime leader, he rallied the British people when they stood virtually alone against the Nazi juggernaut and rallied them and eventually won an extraordinary victory.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Those are two leaders that I admire very much.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I certainly agree with FDR for all the reasons Senator Sanders said.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And I agree about the role that he played both in war and in peace on the economy and defeating fascism around the world.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I would choose Nelson Mandela for his generosity of heart, his understanding of the need for reconciliation.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I want to — I want to follow up on something having to do with leadership, because, you know, today Senator Sanders said that President Obama failed the presidential leadership test.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And this is not the first time that he has criticized President Obama.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: In the past he has called him weak.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: He has called him a disappointment.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: He wrote a forward for a book that basically argued voters should have buyers' remorse when it comes to President Obama's leadership and legacy.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And I just couldn't agree — disagree more with those kinds of comments.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, from my perspective, maybe because I understand what President Obama inherited, not only the worst financial crisis but the antipathy of the Republicans in Congress, I don't think he gets the credit he deserves for being a president...[applause]...who got us out of that...[applause]...put us on firm ground, and has sent us into the future.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And it is a — the kind of criticism that we've heard from Senator Sanders about our president I expect from Republicans.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I do not expect from someone running for the Democratic nomination to succeed President Obama.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That is...[applause]...Madam Secretary, that is a low blow.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have worked with President Obama for the last seven years.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: When President Obama came into office we were losing 800,000 jobs a month, 800,000 jobs a month.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We had a $1.4 trillion deficit.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And the world's financial system is on the verge of collapse.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: As a result of his efforts and the efforts of Joe Biden against unprecedented, I was there in the Senate, unprecedented Republican obstructionism, we have made enormous progress.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents:
[applause]

But you know what?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Last I heard we lived in a democratic society.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Last I heard, a United States senator had the right to disagree with the president, including a president who has done such an extraordinary job.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So I have voiced criticisms.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: You're right.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Maybe you haven't.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But I think to suggest that I have voiced criticism, this blurb that you talk about, you know what the blurb said?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: The blurb said that the next president of the United States has got to be aggressive in bringing people into the political process.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That's what I said.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: That is what I believe.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents:
[applause]

President Obama and I are friends.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: As you know, he came to Vermont to campaign for me when he was a senator.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have worked for his re-election.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: His first election and his re-election.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But I think it is really unfair to suggest that I have not been supportive of the president.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I have been a strong ally with him on virtually every issue.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Do senators have the right to disagree with the president?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Have you ever disagreed with a president?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I suspect you may have.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: [applause]

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: You know, Senator, what I am concerned about, is not disagreement on issues, saying that this is what I would rather do, I don't agree with the president on that, calling the president weak, calling him a disappointment, calling several times that he should have a primary opponent when he ran for re-election in 2012, you know, I think that goes further than saying we have our disagreements.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: As a senator, yes, I was a senator.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I understand we can disagree on the path forward.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But those kinds of personal assessments and charges are ones that I find particularly troubling.

Sents:

Sents: A lot of interesting issues have come together.

Sents: Let me conclude by just saying this.

Sents: There is no president, in my view, not Hillary Clinton, not Bernie Sanders, who has the capability or the power to take on Wall Street, large campaign donors, the corporate media, the big money interests in this country alone.

Sents: This campaign is not just about electing a president.

Sents: What this campaign is about is creating a process for a political revolution in which millions of Americans, working people who have given up on the political process, they don't think anybody hears their pains or their concerns.

Sents: Young people for whom getting involved in politics is as, you know, it's like going to the moon.

Sents: It ain't going to happen.

Sents: Low income people who are not involved in the political process.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What this campaign is not only about electing someone who has the most progressive agenda, it is about bringing tens of millions of people together to demand that we have a government that represents all of us and not just the 1 percent, who today have so much economic and political power.

Sents: Thank you all very much.

Sents: [applause]

Sents: You know, we — we agree that we've got to get unaccountable money out of politics.

Sents: We agree that Wall Street should never be allowed to wreck Main Street again.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But here's the point I want to make tonight.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I am not a single-issue candidate, and I do not believe we live in a single-issue country.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think that a lot of what we have to overcome to break down the barriers that are holding people back, whether it's poison in the water of the children of Flint, or whether it's the poor miners who are being left out and left behind in coal country, or whether it is any other American today who feels somehow put down and oppressed by racism, by sexism, by discrimination against the LGBT community, against the kind of efforts that need to be made to root out all of these barriers, that's what I want to take on.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And here in Wisconsin, I want to reiterate: We've got to stand up for unions and working people who have done it before...[applause]...the American middle class, and who are being attacked by ideologues, by demagogues.

Sents: Yes, does Wall Street and big financial interests, along with drug companies, insurance companies, big oil, all of it, have too much influence?

Sents: You're right.

Sents: But if we were to stop that tomorrow, we would still have the indifference, the negligence that we saw in Flint.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We would still have racism holding people back.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We would still have sexism preventing women from getting equal pay.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We would still have LGBT people who get married on Saturday and get fired on Monday.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And we would still have governors like Scott Walker and others trying to rip out the heart of the middle class by making it impossible to organize and stand up for better wages and working conditions.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So I'm going to keep talking about tearing down all the barriers that stand in the way of Americans fulfilling their potential, because I don't think our country can live up to its potential unless we give a chance to every single American to live up to theirs.
